fields.question_text: Should large financial institutions be subject to stricter government regulations following the 2008 financial crisis?
fields.relevant_info:
Late 2000s financial crisis: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late-2000s_financial_crisis

Various subcategories of financial regulation in the U.S.: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Financial_regulation_in_the_United_States

H.R. 1424 Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008: $700 billion TARP bailout.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-1424

H.R. 4173 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act: introduces new regulation of hedge funds and private equity funds, alters the definition of accredited investors, requires reporting by all public companies on CEO to median employee pay ratios and other compensation data, enforces equitable access to credit for consumers, and provides incentives to promote banking among low- and medium-income residents.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-4173

H.R. 1664 To amend the executive compensation provisions of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act: Would place restrictions on compensation for executives at companies that had participated in certain government assistance programs.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-1664

fields.question_text: Should the United States pledge unconditional support for Israel?
fields.relevant_info:
Israel-United States Relations: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations

H. Res. 921 Condemning the recent attacks against the State of Israel, holding terrorists and their state-sponsors accountable for such attacks, supporting Israel's right to defend itself, and for other purposes: Expresses unconditional support for Israel.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=hr109-921

fields.question_text: Should marijuana be legal for medical purposes?
fields.relevant_info:
Legal history of cannabis in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_history_of_cannabis_in_the_United_States

Cannabis in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_in_the_United_States

H.Amdt. 272 An amendment to prohibit any  funds made available in the Act to the Department of Justice from being used to prevent state lawsauthorizing the use of medical marijuana in those States: An amendment to prohibit any  funds made available in the Act to the Department of Justice from being used to prevent the sale and production of medical marijuana.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=109&amdt=h272

fields.question_text: Should women be allowed to have an abortion?
fields.relevant_info:
H.AMDT. 368 Maintain Mexico City Policy on International Abortion Funding: would have upheld the prohibition against federal funding of international organizations that perform or promote abortion as a method of family planning.
http://downloads.frcaction.org/EF/EF08I02.pdf

H.AMDT 594 Restrict Funding to Planned Parenthood: Would have restricted federal funding for abortions by withholding from Planned Parenthood any of the $331 million appropriated for Title X family planning services.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=110&amdt=h594

H.R. 3 No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act: Prohibits any funding from being appropriated for abortions. Also prohibits federal funds from being used for any health benefits coverage that includes coverage of abortion.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3

H.R. 3293 FY 2010 Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act: Would have prohibited the disbursement of Title X family planning funds to Planned Parenthood Federal of America because the organization uses its own money to provide women with abortion care.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-3293

H.Amdt. 367 Amendment replaced language in the bill concerning the use of funds provided for family planning/reproductive health: allowing taxpayer funded contraceptives to be given to international organizations that perform and promote abortions as a method of family planning.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=110&amdt=h367

fields.question_text: Should the Guantanamo Bay detention camp remain in operation?
fields.relevant_info:
Guantanamo Bay detention camp: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay_detention_camp#Criticism_and_condemnation

H.R. 5136 National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2011: Prohibit the use of funds authorized in the bill to transfer or release individuals detained at the U.S. facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, into the United States.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-5136&tab=summary

H.AMDT. 270 Require Videotaping Of All Intelligence Interrogations: Amendment that would require the videotaping of all intelligence interrogations of persons in the custody of the Defense Department, excluding tactical questioning as defined by the Army Field Manual on Human Intelligence Collector Operations. It would require the department to submit to Congress, no later than 30 days after the bill's enactment, a report containing guidelines for interrogation videotaping.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=111&amdt=h270

H.R. 2892 Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2010: Would prohibit the transfer of detainees held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to the United States except for prosecution; place detainees on the "no-fly" list; and bar the use of funds to provide them benefits. It also would extend the authorization of the E-Verify program for three years.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-2892&tab=summary

fields.question_text: Should openly gay individuals serve in the military?
fields.relevant_info: S. 4023 Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010: Repeals "Don't Ask, Don't Tell."

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. government aid homeowners in financing energy efficiency renovations?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 4785 Rural Energy Savings Program Act: Would authorize $5 billion over five years to create two energy efficiency loan programs, including $850 million annually for the Home Star Energy Efficiency Loan Program to support loans to finance energy efficiency home renovations and $150 million annually for the Rural Energy Savings Program to make loans to eligible entities for energy efficiency measures in rural areas.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr4785

fields.question_text: Should the government be funding environmental education programs for students and the public?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 3644 Ocean, Coastal, and Watershed Education Act: To authorize and increase funding for two key National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) education programs. Helps NOAA establish new partnerships with top science centers, aquaria and education institutions to deliver environmental education materials to thousands of teachers who educate students and the public.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr3644

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. allow long-time illegal immigrants that are in good standing to gain legal status as well as expand the guest worker visa program?
fields.relevant_info:
Illegal immigration to the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States

H.R. 5281 Development, Relief, and Education for Alien Minors Act of 2010: This bill would provide conditional permanent residency to certain undocumented immigrants of good moral character who graduate from US high schools, arrived in the US as minors, and lived in the country continuously for at least five years prior to the bill's enactment.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-5281&tab=summary

H.R. 4437 Border Protection, Antiterrorism, and Illegal Immigration Control Act of 2005: Would further militarize the border, allow low-level immigration officials to expel anyone found within 100 miles of the border believed to be a recently arrived undocumented immigrant without a hearing, expand mandatory detention of non-citizens who are not shown to be a danger or a flight risk and erode the right to judicial review. would designate unlawful presence as a criminal, rather than a civil, offense. It also would increase penalties for a variety of immigration-related crimes.  It  would  create  a  mandatory  program  under  which  all  employers  would  have  to electronically verify employees' work eligibility with the federal government.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-4437

H.R. 6061 Secure Fence Act of 2006: The evaluation and construction of physical barriers and advanced technology in reinforcing fencing along the southern U.S. border, and assisting in the enforcement of immigration security in specified areas.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-6061

H.R. 6095 Immigration Law Enforcement Act of 2006: Would reaffirm that state and local law enforcement personnel  have  the  inherent  authority  to  investigate,  identify,  arrest,  and  detain  aliens  in  the normal course of duties for the purpose of assisting enforcement of U.S. immigration laws. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-6095

fields.question_text: In general, was the Obama Administration's health care reform legislation beneficial for the United States?
fields.relevant_info:
Health care in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States

Health care reform in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_care_reform_in_the_United_States

H.R. 3590 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act: The principal health care reform legislation of the 111th United States Congress. PPACA reforms certain aspects of the private health insurance industry and public health insurance programs, increases insurance coverage of pre-existing conditions, expands access to insurance to over 30 million Americans, and increases projected national medical spending while lowering projected Medicare spending.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-3590&tab=summary

H.R. 3962 Preservation of Access to Care for Medicare Beneficiaries and Pension Relief Act of 2010: provide more affordable, quality coverage for all, call for shared responsibility by individuals, employers and government, and expand health insurance coverage choices.  The bill includes provisions to make health insurance and health care services more affordable and to retain and strengthen employer-sponsored insurance and extend this responsibility across a broader spectrum of employers.  It includes progressive financing provisions to ensure that middle income families do not take on an even greater burden for securing comprehensive health insurance coverage for their families.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-3962

H.R. 4872 Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010: Increasing the tax credits to buy insurance.
Eliminates several of the special deals given to senators. Offer more generous subsidies to lower income groups. Households below 150% of the federal poverty level would pay 2% to 4% of their income on premiums. Health plans would cover 94% of the cost of benefits. Increases the Pell Grant scholarship award.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Care_and_Education_Reconciliation_Act_of_2010

fields.question_text: Should the EPA's emissions standards be based on the scientific finding that greenhouse gases endanger human health and the environment?
fields.relevant_info:
Environmental Law: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_law

S. Amdt. 183 To prohibit the Administrator of the Environmental Protection...: To repeal the scientific finding by the EpA that greenhouse gases endanger human health and the environment, to permanently block the EPA from reducing greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act, and to undermine fuel economy standards. http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=s183

S. 1720 Jobs Through Growth Act: Would prevent the EPA from cleaning up harmful pollution from some of the nation’s biggest polluters, reduce oversight for drilling, open public lands to tar sands development by private companies, and prohibit California from ensuring that enough water is allocated to protect salmon and Delta smelt.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s112-1720

S. 3072 Stationary Source Regulations Delay Act: Would put a stop-work order on the EPA’s commonsense steps to reduce carbon pollution from power plants and refineries, among other large polluters.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s111-3072

H.R. 4753 Stationary Source Regulations Delay Act: Would put a stop-work order on the EPA’s commonsense steps to reduce carbon pollution from power plants and refineries, among other large polluters. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-4753

S. 910 Energy Tax Prevention Act of 2011: To repeal the scientific finding by the EpA that greenhouse gases endanger human health and the environment, to permanently block the EPA from reducing greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act, and to undermine fuel economy standards. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-910

H. Amdt. 41 Amendment sought to reduce by $2,750,000 the Bureau of Land...: To cut by 90% the bill’s allocation for the Land and Water Conservation fund (LWCf), which is funded by oil royalties and helps expand protected lands and fund local projects such as city parks.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=h41

H. Amdt. 715 An amendment to reduce the various accounts by $3,000,231,000 and..: The amendment would drastically slash spending from a slew of critical conservation agencies such as the fish and Wildlife Service and the National park Service, as well as from environmental programs such as the Clean Water State revolving funds and the Drinking Water State revolving funds.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=h715

H. Amdt. 800 Amendment requires the EPA's administrator to consider the...: Amendment would require the EpA to define healthy air based on the “feasibility and cost” to polluting industries, and would compel the EPA to accept standards that fail to protect public health. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=h800

H.R. 2401 Transparency in Regulatory Analysis of Impacts on the Nation Act of 2011: Bill would allow for the indefinite delay of two clean air safeguards (the Cross-State Air pollution rule and the mercury and Air Toxics Standards for power plants). Essentially eliminates the health-based underpinning of the Clean Air Act.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-2401

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. have a contingency plan for military operations in Iran?
fields.relevant_info:
H.Amdt. 186 Amendment sought to prohibit funds authorized in the bill from being obligated or expended to plan a contingency operation in Iran: Would prohibit funds authorized in the bill for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan from being used to plan a contingency operation in Iran.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=110&amdt=h186

fields.question_text: Were you in support of the $700 billion TARP bailout in 2008 designed to stabilize the economy?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 1424 Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008: $700 billion TARP bailout.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-1424

fields.question_text: In the public education system, should math and science be encouraged more then other subjects?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2272 America COMPETES Act: Designed to encourage math, sciene, engineering in public schools.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-2272

fields.question_text: Was the 2009 economic stimulus package an appropriate response to the country's economic recession?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 1 American Reinvestment and Recovery Act of 2009: An act making supplemental appropriations for job preservation and creation, infrastructure investment, energy efficiency and science, assistance to the unemployed, and State and local fiscal stabilization, for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2009, and for other purposes.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-1

H.R. 3221 Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008: Increases the national debt limit from $9.82 trillion to $10.62 trillion. Allocates $3.92 billion in grants to States and other units of local government to redevelop abandoned and foreclosed property and $180 million to the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation. Establishes the Federal Housing Finance Agency, with regulatory authority over Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, the Federal Home Loan Banks, and the Office of Finance. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-3221

fields.question_text: Should there be a clearly defined exit strategy for U.S. armed forces in Afghanistan?
fields.relevant_info:
S. 3197 A bill to require a plan for the safe, orderly, and expeditious redeployment of United States Armed Forces from Afghanistan: Directs the President, by the earlier of January 1, 2011, or 90 days after the enactment of this Act, to submit to Congress a plan for the safe, orderly, and expeditious redeployment of U.S. Armed Forces from Afghanistan.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s111-3197

fields.question_text: Should the federal government be required to maintain a balanced budget?
fields.relevant_info:
H.J.Res. 2 Balanced Budget Amendment: Requiring that the state cannot spend more than its income.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=hj112-2

fields.question_text: Should the TSA be permitted to use whole-body Imaging as a primary method for screening airline passengers?
fields.relevant_info:
H.Amdt. 172 Amendment prohibits the TSA from using Whole Body-Imaging machines: Amendment prohibits the TSA from using Whole Body-Imaging machines for primary screening at airports; and would require the TSA to give passengers the option of a pat-down search in lieu of going through a WBI machine.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=111&amdt=h172

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. bar habeas corpus appeals and instead use military tribunals to try foreign detainees deemed to be unlawful enemy combatants?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 6166 Military Commissions Act of 2006: Retroactively stripped federal courts of authority to consider habeas corpus petitions and other legal actions by foreign detainees, provided retroactive immunity to civilians who authorized or ordered illegal acts of torture and abuse, and set up military commissions that can order executions of defendants based on evidence that the defendant cannot see and that was obtained only as the result of horrific abuse.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-6166

fields.question_text: Should states be required to develop state-wide student assessments in order to receive federal funding?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 1 No Child Left Behind Act of 2001: Determines funding based on standardized test performance. Requires states to develop assessments in basic skills to be given to all students in certain grades, if those states are to receive federal funding for schools. Funding tied to NCLB received a 40.4% increase from $17.4 billion in 2001 to $24.4 billion.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h107-1

fields.question_text: Is the detention and interrogation of detainees at Guantanamo Bay essential to the defense of the U.S. and its allies?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2892 Prohibits Transfer Of Guantanamo Detainees To U.S., Except For Prosecution: $44.1 billion in fiscal 2010, including $42.8 billion in discretionary funds, for the Homeland Security Department and related activities. It would provide $10.1 billion for Customs and Border Protection; $7.7 billion for the Transportation Security Administration, not including offsetting fees; $10.1 billion for the Coast Guard; $1.5 billion for the Secret Service and $7.1 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency. It would prohibit the transfer of detainees held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to the United States except for prosecution; place detainees on the "no-fly" list; and bar the use of funds to provide them benefits. It also would extend the authorization of the E-Verify program for three years.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-2892

H.Amdt. 487 Amendment adds language expressing the sense of Congress concerning the capture, detention and interrogation of international terrorists; and the detention and lawful, humane interrogation by the U.S. of detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba: to express the sense of Congress that the capture, detention and interrogation of international terrorists are essential to the successful prosecution of the Global War on Terrorism and to the defense of the U.S., its citizens, and coalition partners from future terrorist attacks; and that the detention and lawful, humane interrogation by the U.S. of detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba is essential to the defense of the U.S. and its coalition partners and to the successful prosecution of the Global War on Terrorism.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=109&amdt=h487

fields.question_text: Should the government have recently raised its debt ceiling?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 4314 To permit continued financing of Government operations: Increases the national debt limit by $290 billion, from $12.1 trillion to $12.4 trillion.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-4314

H.R. 1954 To implement the President's request to increase the statutory limit on the public debt: Would increase the national debt limit by $2.4 trillion without enacting corresponding provisions to alter spending trajectory.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-1954

fields.question_text: Should advocacy organizations be required to release the identities of their donors?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 5175 Democracy is Strengthened by Casting Light on Spending in Elections Act: Included a provision obligating many advocacy organizations that wish to speak out on candidates and, in certain situations, political issues, to release the identities of many of their donors, while allowing a few large mainstream organizations to preserve the privacy of their donors.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-5175

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. expand oil shale mining operations?
fields.relevant_info: H.R. 3408 PIONEERS Act: No later than January 1, 2016, the Secretary of the Interior shall hold no less than 5 separate commercial lease sales in areas considered to have the most potential for oil shale development, as determined by the Secretary, in areas nominated through public comment. Each lease sale shall be for an area of not less than 25,000 acres, and in multiple lease blocs.

fields.question_text: Should the federal government increase the amount of financial aid it gives to college students?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 4137 Higher Education Opportunity Act: Designed to ensure equal college opportunities and fair learning environments for students with disabilities, expanded college access for low-income and minority students, streamlined the federal student financial aid application, and provide supports to help students transition from community colleges to four-year programs.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-4137

fields.question_text: Should local governments have the authority to seize private property for the stated purpose of economic development?
fields.relevant_info:
Eminent domain: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eminent_domain

H.Amdt. 427 An amendment to prohibit use of funds in the bill to enforce the judgment of the United States Supreme Court in the case of Kelo v. New London: Prohibits federal funds from being used by local governments to take private property for economic development.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=109&amdt=h427

fields.question_text: Should the government reduce funding for its conservation projects?
fields.relevant_info:
Conservation in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_in_the_United_States

H.Amdt. 41 Amendment sought to reduce by $2,750,000 the Bureau of Land Management, Land Acquisition and reducing the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Land Acquisition by $15,055,000.: To cut by 90% the bill’s allocation for the Land and Water Conservation fund (LWCf), which is funded by oil royalties and helps expand protected lands and fund local projects such as city parks.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=h41

fields.question_text: When implementing environmental regulations, should the economic cost to the polluting industries be taken into account?
fields.relevant_info:
Environmental Law: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_law#Federal_regulation

H.Amdt. 800 An amendment numbered 11 printed in House Report 112-213 to update…: Amendment would require the EpA to define healthy air based on the “feasibility and cost” to polluting industries, and would compel the EPA to accept standards that fail to protect public health. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=h800

fields.question_text: Should the EPA have the power to regulate carbon emissions from power plants and refineries?
fields.relevant_info:
Greenhouse Gas: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_gas

S.Amdt. 183 To prohibit the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency from promulgating any regulation concerning, taking action relating to, or taking into consideration the emission of a greenhouse gas to address climate change: To repeal the scientific finding by the EpA that greenhouse gases endanger human health and the environment, to permanently block the EPA from reducing greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act, and to undermine fuel economy standards. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=112&amdt=s183

S.J.Res. 26 A joint resolution disapproving a rule submitted by the Environmental Protection Agency relating to the endangerment finding and the cause or contribute findings for greenhouse gases under section 202(a) of the Clean Air Act: Resolution would negate an attempt by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to regulate carbon-dioxide emissions.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=sj111-26

fields.question_text: Were you supportive of the invasion of Iraq in 2003?
fields.relevant_info:
2003 Invasion of Iraq: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq

H.J.Res. 114 Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002: Passage of the joint resolution that would authorize President Bush to use the U.S. military as he deems necessary and appropriate to defend U.S. national security against Iraq and enforce U.N. Security Council resolutions regarding Iraq.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=hj107-114

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. continue development of defense systems to intercept missiles?
fields.relevant_info:
National missile defense: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_missile_defense

H.Amdt. 266 Amendment sought to provide that it is U.S. policy to continue missile defense testing: Would increase the amount authorized for the Missile Defense Agency by $1.2 billion, offset by a reduction of the same amount for defense environmental cleanup. It would provide that it be U.S. policy to continue development of systems to intercept missiles.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=111&amdt=h266

fields.question_text: Should marriage in the United States be explicitly defined as the union of a man and a woman?
fields.relevant_info:
H.J.Res. 88 Marriage Protection Amendment: Would have amended the United States Constitution and defined marriage as between one man and one woman.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=hj109-88

fields.question_text: Should skill level and potential contribution to society be the basis for granting immigrants  permanent U.S. residency?
fields.relevant_info:
Diversity Immigrant Visa: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity_Immigrant_Visa

H.Amdt. 650 Amendment eliminates the visa lottery program: Would eliminate the diversity  visa  program,  otherwise  known  as  the  visa  lottery.  The  diversity  visa  program  sets aside  50,000  permanent resident  visas (green  cards)  annually,  but  issues  them randomly  to eligible  applicants  instead  of  pursuant  to  an  analysis  of  the  alien’s  skill  level  or  potential contribution to society.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/vote.xpd?vote=h2005-653&sort=vote

fields.question_text: Should the minimum wage be increased?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2 Fair Minimum Wage Act of 2007: increased over time the federal minimum wage from $5.15 to $7.25 an hour.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-2

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. expand offshore drilling?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 1229 Putting the Gulf of Mexico Back to Work Act: Would expand offshore drilling and make it more dangerous by enacting oversight standards that are weaker than those that were in place before the catastrophic 2010 Gulf oil spill disaster. The legislation would impose a rushed and arbitrary time period of just 30 days for the Interior Secretary to approve or deny drilling permits, and it would grant automatic approval if no action is taken within 60 days.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-1229

fields.question_text: Should law enforcement officers be allowed to search a home or business without the owner’s or the occupant’s permission or knowledge?
fields.relevant_info:
Patriot Act: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriot_Act

H.R. 3162 Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT Act): Authorizes indefinite detentions of immigrants. Allows law enforcement officers to search a home or business without the owner’s or the occupant’s permission or knowledge. Allows the search of telephone, e-mail, and financial records without a court order, and the expanded access of law enforcement agencies to business records, including library and financial records. Since its passage, several legal challenges have been brought against the act, and Federal courts have ruled that a number of provisions are unconstitutional.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h107-3162

fields.question_text: Should sex education programs advocate for use of contraceptives as opposed to abstinence?
fields.relevant_info:
Sex education in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_education_in_the_United_States

S.Amdt. 4689 To authorize grants to carry out programs to provide education on preventing teen pregnancies: Would have increased funding for comprehensive sex-ed programs, steered funding toward condom distribution and undermined abstinence-untilmarriage education programs.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/amendment.xpd?session=109&amdt=s4689

fields.question_text: Should the government be required to fully disclose all entities and organizations that have received federal funding?
fields.relevant_info:
S. 2590 Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006: A bill to require full disclosure of all entities and organizations receiving Federal funds. Established USAspending.gov, which allows citizens to track government spending.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s109-2590

fields.question_text: Should companies involved in offshore drilling be required to equip their vessels with pollution control technology?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2021 Jobs and Energy Permitting Act of 2011: Bill would exempt these companies from requirements to apply available pollution control technology to vessels involved in offshore drilling, and waive permit reviews by the EpA’s Environmental Appeals Board.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-2021

fields.question_text: Should states have the authority to decide whether or not offshore drilling takes place in their waters?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 1231 Reversing President Obama's Offshore Moratorium Act: To amend the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to require that each 5-year offshore oil and gas leasing program offer leasing in the areas with the most prospective oil and gas resources, to establish a domestic oil and natural gas production goal, and for other purposes.Would ensure that drilling occurs off the beaches of the entire East Coast down to North Carolina, off the Southern California coast, and in the Arctic ocean and Alaska’s salmon-rich Bristol Bay—regardless of whether a state objects to such drilling.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-1231

fields.question_text: Should religious schools be eligible for federal funding?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 471 Scholarships for Opportunity and Results Act: Would reauthorize and expand federal funding for private and religious school vouchers in the District of Columbia.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-471

fields.question_text: Should the government invest in research and development of more energy efficient technologies for our automobiles?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 3246 Advanced Vehicle Technology Act of 2009: To provide for a program of research, development, demonstration and commercial application in vehicle technologies at the Department of Energy.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-3246

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. increase its use of nuclear power?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 6 Energy Policy Act of 2005: Support for advanced nuclear technology. Federal loan guarantees for advanced nuclear reactors or other emission-free technologies up to 80% of the project cost. Federal risk insurance of $2 billion to cover regulatory delays in full-power operation of the first six advanced new plants. Production tax credits.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-6

fields.question_text: Should the government provide loan gaurantees and tax breaks for technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions?
fields.relevant_info:
Renewable Energy: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy

Renewable energy in the United States: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_the_United_States

H.R. 2454 American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009: To create clean energy jobs, achieve energy independence, reduce global warming pollution and transition to a clean energy economy. This is the so-called Waxman-Markey cap and trade bill and was considered more comprehensive and ambitious than both the Lieberman-Warner Bill and President Obama’s proposal. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-2454

H.R. 3585 Solar Technology Roadmap Act: Would provide additional federal funding to advance U.S. research, development, and demonstration efforts related to solar technology,
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-3585

fields.question_text: Should Medicaid be expanded in order to cover more uninsured Americans?
Should the U.S. have a national, government-run health care system similar to those in Europe and Canada?
Should all U.S. citizens be required to have health insurance?
Should the federal government be promoting the development of more charter schools in the U.S.?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2218 Empowering Parents through Quality Charter Schools Act: To promote the development of high-performing charter schools and give students in under-performing public schools more educational options. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr2218

fields.question_text: Should the U.S. use a cap and trade system in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2454 American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009: To create clean energy jobs, achieve energy independence, reduce global warming pollution and transition to a clean energy economy. This is the so-called Waxman-Markey cap and trade bill and was considered more comprehensive and ambitious than both the Lieberman-Warner Bill and President Obama’s proposal. 
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr2454

fields.question_text: Should health insurance companies that issue long term plans be required to address disputed claims through a third-party review process?
fields.relevant_info:
S. 3230 Long Term Care Insurance Integrity Act of 2012: A bill to require issuers of long term care insurance to establish third-party review processes for disputed claims.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/s3230

fields.question_text: Should employers be required to take responsibility for a greater percentage of employees' health insurance expenses?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 4872 Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010: Reduces from 9.8% to 9.5% of a taxpayer's household income the maximum amount an employee's required contribution to an employer-sponsored plan may be for such employee to be treated as eligible for employer-sponsored minimum essential coverage. Increases the percentage of employer cost sharing for the out-of-pocket expenses of individuals with household incomes between 100% and 400% of the federal poverty line.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr4872

fields.question_text: Should the Food and Drug Administration have a less thorough review process for prescriptions drugs in order to increase availablility to patients?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 5651 Food and Drug Administration Reform Act of 2012: Directs the FDA to use an accelerated approval program already taken advantage of by cancer and AIDS treatments that requires a lower standard of evidence for initial clearance of medicines for life-threatening diseases.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/112-2012/h294

fields.question_text: Should makers of generic drugs be required to pay fees similar to those paid by brand-name manufacturers to have their drugs reviewed by the FDA?
fields.relevant_info:
S. 3187 Food and Drug Administration Safety and Innovation Act: Expands the user-fee program from traditional, brand-name drug makers and medical-device makers to generic drug makers and firms making "biosimilar" knockoffs of expensive drugs. Estimated $6 billion in user fees from 2013 through 2017 would pay for about 60% of the FDA's drug-and-device-review costs, the agency estimated.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/s3187

fields.question_text: Should states be able to set their own water quality standards separate from those of the federal government?
fields.relevant_info:
H.R. 2018 Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011: Restricts EPA’s ability to second-guess or delay a state’s permitting and water quality certification decisions under the CWA once EPA has already approved a state’s program.
http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr2018

fields.question_text: Should a certain percentage of HIV/AIDS prevention funding be allocated only to programs that promote abstinence?
fields.relevant_info:
H.Amdt. 364 Maintain Abstinence and Faithfulness Programs to Prevent Spread of HIV/AIDs: Restores a carefully negotiated prevention policy which requires a third of HIV/AIDs prevention funding to be spent for “abstinence-until-marriage” and “be-faithful."
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HZ364:

fields.answer_text: yes!
Yes, an attack on a person because of their sexuality, gender or disability constitutes a hate crime.
No, sexuality, gender or disability should not apply to the definition of a hate crime.
Yes, human embryonic stem cells should be used for research without any limitations.
Human embryonic stem cell research can occur as long as the embryo is not destroyed in the process
No, human embryos should not be included in stem cell research.
Yes, large financial institutions should be subject to stricter government regulations.
Yes, women should have the right to an abortion.
No, the TARP bailout was the wrong action taken.
Yes, the TARP bailout was the right measure in order to stabilize the failing economy.
No, women should not be allowed to have an abortion.
Yes, the detention center at Guantanamo Bay should remain open.
No, the U.S. should not have expanded public health insurance.
No, the detention center should be closed down.
The U.S. should invest in tighter security along its borders.
The U.S. should work towards greater use of nuclear power.
The U.S. should take concrete steps towards greater use of renewable energy.
The U.S. should begin offshore drilling to decrease its dependence on foreign oil.
Yes, the recent expansion of publicly-funded health insurance was good for this country.
The U.S. should develop a more comprehensive system that prevents illegal immigrants from accessing taxpayer-funded benefits.
The U.S. should take more steps towards detaining and expelling illegal aliens.
Same-sex couples should be able to legally marry.
The U.S. should allow for more avenues for immigrants to gain residency.
Yes, the U.S. should have a plan in place in the event that invading Iran proves necessary.
Same-sex couples should be prohibited from legal marriage.
Homosexuals should be able to serve openly in the U.S. Armed Forces.
A publicly funded system should be the dominant form of health care in the U.S.
There should be both a public and private system that are on equal footing.
There should be a publicly funded system but it should play a minimal role.
There should be no publicly funded health care in the U.S.
Yes, companies should be regulated by environmental laws.
No, it is not necessary that the U.S. have a plan in place for invading Iran.
No, companies should not be regulated by environmental laws.
Laws meant to protect homosexuals from workplace discrimination are not necessary.
No, large financial institutions should not be subject to stricter government regulation.
Yes, the United States should support Israel unconditionally.
Homosexuals should not serve openly in the U.S. Armed Forces.
There should be laws protecting homosexuals from workplace discrimination.
No, the United States should not support Israel unconditionally.
Yes, marijuana should be legal for medical purposes.
No, marijuana should not be legal for medical purposes.
Yes, math and science should be encouraged more than other subjects.
No, math and science should not be encouraged over other subjects.
Yes, government programs are an effective measure for stimulating the economy.
No, government programs with the aim of stimulating the economy should not be implemented.
Yes, there should be a clearly defined exit strategy for American troops in Afghanistan.
No, setting a strict timetable for withdrawal would be premature at this time.
No, the government should be able to borrow money when necessary.
Yes, we should never spend more then we have.
Yes, passengers should not be subjected to Whole-Body Imaging.
No, Whole-Body Imaging is an effective and necessary method against crime and terrorism.
Yes, foreign detainees should have the same legal rights such as the right to a fair trial.
No, foreign detainees should not be granted the same rights enjoyed by U.S. citizens.
No, standardized test performance should not be a main criteria for allocating funds for public schools.
Yes, standardized test performance should be a main criteria for allocating funds for public schools.
Yes, the detention and interrogation of detainees at Guantanamo is essential to ensuring the safety of Americans and their allies.
No, detaining and interrogating detainees at Guantanamo is not an essential part of keeping America and its allies safe.
The U.S. should not create any more avenues for illegal immigrants to gain residency.
Yes, raising the debt ceiling was a necessary measure.
No, the government should not have given itself the ability to take on more debt.
Yes, advocacy organizations should be required to reveal the identities of their donors.
No, advocacy organizations should have the right to withhold the identities of their donors.
Yes, it is perfectly acceptable to have religious displays on government property.
No, government property should be free of religious displays.
Yes, the government should be doing more to help students pay for college.
No, the government does not need to commit more funds to college students.
Yes, local governments should be able to seize private property when it is necessary for economic development.
No, local governments should have no right to seize private property for supposed economic development.
Yes, the government needs to be an active player in conservation efforts.
No, the government does not need to be so committed to conservation efforts.
Yes, the economic costs to polluters need to be factored in when applying environmental regulations.
No, if environmental regulations are to make a meaningful impact, they cannot be based on the economic costs to the polluters.
Yes, the U.S. must take concrete steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
No, the U.S. should not be occupied with trying to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Yes, invading Iraq was an appropriate action.
No, the U.S. should not have invaded Iraq.
Yes, the U.S. should continue developing a system that can defend against missile attacks.
No, we should not be committing resources to such a project.
Yes, marriage needs to be explicitly defined in this country as between one man and one woman.
No, the U.S. should not define marriage as being solely between one man and one woman.
Yes, immigrants should be welcomed to this country based on their skill level and their potential contributions to society.
No, all immigrants should have an equal chance of gaining residency regardless of skill level.
Yes, the minimum wage needs to be increased.
No, the minimum wage does not need to be increased.
Yes, the U.S. should expand offshore drilling.
No, the U.S. should not expand offshore drilling.
Yes, law enforcement officers should be allowed to search a home or business without the owner's permission or knowledge.
No, law enforcement should not be allowed such freedom to search homes and businesses.
Yes, sex education programs should be teaching contraception, not abstinence.
No, sex education programs should not be advocating contraception over abstinence.
Yes, the government must fully disclose all entities and organizations that it is funding.
No, the government should not have to disclose every entity and organization that it funds.
Yes, rigs and vessels involved in offshore drilling need to be equipped with the proper technology to protect the environment.
No, rigs and vessels should not be required to be equipped with pollution control technology.
Yes, states should be able prohibit offshore drilling if they want.
No, states should not have a say over whether or not offshore drilling takes place in their waters.
No, religious schools should not be eligible for federal funding.
Yes, religious schools should be eligible for federal funding.
Yes, the government should be investing resources to make our automobiles more efficient.
No, the government should not commit resources to such a project.
Yes, nuclear power is an energy source we should be making more use of.
No, we should not be increasing our use of nuclear power.
Yes, the U.S. needs to be making meaningful investments in renewable energy.
No, the U.S. does not need to be putting so much effort into using more renewable energy.
Yes, more people should be insured by Medicaid.
No, Medicaid should not be expanded to insure more people
Yes, the U.S. should work towards creating a national health care system similar to those found in Europe and Canada.
No, the U.S. should not have a national health care system similar to those found in Europe and Canada.
Yes, all citizens should be required to have some form of health insurance.
No, citizens should not be required to have health insurance.
Yes, same-sex couples be able to legally marry.
Yes, homosexuals should be allowed to serve openly in the U.S. Armed Forces.
No, homosexuals should not be allowed to serve openly in the U.S. Armed Forces.
Yes, the government should be helping households finance home renovations that would increase energy efficiency.
No, the government should not be involved in financing such initiatives.
Yes, the government should be funding programs to educate students and the public about the environment.
No, the government should not commit resources for such education programs.
Yes, foreigners should have more avenues through which they can enter or gain legal status in the U.S.
No, the U.S. should not be creating more avenues for foreigners to enter or gain legal status.
In general, yes, the Obama Administration's health care reform legislation was beneficial for the United States.
No, the Obama Administration's recent health care reform legislation was no beneficial for the United States.
Not as a whole. Some provisions are beneficial for the country but others are not.
Yes, greenhouse gas emissions should be regulated based on the scientific finding concerning their potentiialy harmful effects.
No, the implementation of greenhouse gas regulations should not be based on such grounds.
Yes, large financial institutions should be subject to stricter government regulations now.
No, large financial institutions should not be subject to stricter government regulations.
Yes, the 2009 stimulus package was an appropriate response to the recession.
No, the 2009 stimulus package was not an appropriate response to the recession.
Yes, whole-body Imaging is an effective and necessary method against crime and terrorism.
No, passengers should not be subjected to whole-body Imaging.
Yes, foreign detainees should be tried by military tribunals as opposed to civilian courts.
No, foreign detainees should not be tried by military tribunals.
Yes, federal funding for states should be tied to their ability to establish measurable goals through state-wide student assessments.
No, states should not be required to devise state-wide assessments of their students in order to receive federal funding.
Yes, the detention and interrogation of detainees at Guantanamo is essential to ensuring the safety of America and its allies.
No, detaining and interrogating detainees at Guantanamo is not an essential part of keeping America and its allies safe.
Yes, the government should reduce spending on its environmental conservation projects.
No, the government should not reduce funding to these projects.
Yes, the EPA should have the authority to regulate emissions from power plants and refineries.
No, the EPA should not have the authority to place such restrictions on power plants and refineries.
Yes, marriage needs to be explicitly defined in this country as between one man and one woman.
No, the U.S. should not define marriage as being solely between one man and one woman.
Yes, the government should use loans and tax breaks to create a favoroable environment for clean energy?
No, the government does not need to be so active in fostering a favorable environment for these technologies.
Yes, openly gay individuals be able to serve in the U.S. Armed Forces.
No, openly gay individuals should not serve in the U.S. Armed Forces.
Yes, the government should be helping households finance home renovations that would increase energy efficiency.
No, the government should not be involved in financing such initiatives.
Yes, the U.S. should expand oil shale mining to help meet our energy needs.
No, the U.S. does not need to be expanding oil shale mining.
Yes, the presence of charter schools in the U.S. should be expanded.
No, the presence of charter schools in the U.S. does not need to be expanded.
Yes, a cap and trade system is an effective way to curb greenhouse gas emissions.
No, a cap and trade system is not the best way to reduce greenhouse gases.
Yes, these disputed claims should be presided over by a third-party review process.
No, such disputes do not require a third-party review process in order to be resolved.
Yes, employers should be required to take responsibility for a greater amount of employees' health insurance expenses.
No, employers should not be required to take responsibility for a greater precentage of employees' health insurance expenses.
Yes, the FDA should make it easier for new presecription drugs to reach the market.
No, the FDA should not be making it easier for new prescription drugs to reach the market.
Yes, makers of generic drugs should pay fees to have their drugs reviewed by the FDA, just as their brand-name counterparts are required to do.
No, makers of generic drugs do not need to be subject to fees to have their drugs reviewed.
Yes, states should be able to set their own standards for water quality.
No, the states should not be able to set their own standards for water quality.
Yes, a certain amount of HIV/AIDS prevention funding should be reserved only for programs promoting abstinence.
No, the government should not be allocating HIV/AIDS prevention funding based on such criteria.

fields.title: Should large financial institutions be subject to stricter government regulations following the 2008 financial crisis?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on TARP bailout, executive compensation, the federal reserve, SEC, concept of "too big to fail."

fields.title: Should the United States pledge unconditional support for Israel?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on funds allocated for Israel, U.S. support in the event of an attack by Iran.

fields.title: Should marijuana be legal for medical purposes?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on medical marijuana, the war on drugs and funds allocated for it, sentencing, various levels of decriminalization.

fields.title: Should women be allowed to have an abortion?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should be concerned with the various stages of development of the fetus as well as funding for Planned Parenthood.

fields.title: Should the Guantanamo Bay detention camp remain in operation?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should be concerned with interrogation techniques, transfer of prisoners and legal rights of prisoners.

fields.title: Should the U.S. allow long-time illegal immigrants that are in good standing to gain legal status as well as expand the guest worker visa program?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should include criteria for residency, enforcement of deportation policies, access to education/healthcare/employment, border protection.

fields.title: In general, was the Obama Administration's health care reform legislation beneficial for the United States?
fields.summary: This question will likely need to be either reworded or altered altogether since it is not clarifying whether it concerns Medicare or not.

fields.title: Should the EPA's emissions standards be based on the scientific finding that greenhouse gases endanger human health and the environment?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on regulation reform, tax laws, renewable/alternative energy funding, industry regulations.

fields.title: Should the U.S. have a contingency plan for military operations in Iran?
Were you in support of the $700 billion TARP bailout in 2008 designed to stabilize the economy?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on similar financial reform, executive compensation, etc.

fields.title: In the public education system, should math and science be encouraged more than other subjects?
Was the 2009 economic stimulus package an appropriate response to the country's economic recession?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on more specific government initiatives, tax credits, public works projects.

fields.title: Should there be a clearly defined exit strategy for U.S. armed forces in Afghanistan?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on presence of U.S. in general: contractors, advisors, businesses.

fields.title: Should the federal government be required to maintain a balanced budget?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on increasing the debt ceiling, general government spending, various taxing strategies.

fields.title: Should the TSA be permitted to use whole-body Imaging as a primary method for screening airline passengers?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on similar security practices like more specific uses of WBI, pat-downs and security presence at train stations.

fields.title: Should the U.S. bar habeas corpus appeals and instead use military tribunals to try foreign detainees deemed to be unlawful enemy combatants?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on use of criminal vs. civil vs. military courts, varying degrees of legal rights.

fields.title: Should states be required to develop state-wide student assessments in order to receive federal funding?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on different options for grant programs, the role of standardized tests.

fields.title: Is the detention and interrogation of detainees at Guantanamo Bay essential to the defense of the U.S. and its allies?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on why they would be transferred; either because fo their sentencing or the closing of the detention camp.

fields.title: Should the government have recently raised its debt ceiling?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should concern spending trajectory.

fields.title: Should advocacy organizations be required to release the identities of their donors?
Should the federal government increase the amount of financial aid it gives to college students?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on specific criteria for financial aid, the role of community college.

fields.title: Should local governments have the authority to seize private property for the stated purpose of economic development?
fields.summary: Any other legislation related to eminent domain.

fields.title: Should the government reduce funding for its conservation projects?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on specific conservation projects and methods, land acquisition, opening lands up for mining/drilling.

fields.title: When implementing environmental regulations, should the economic cost to the polluting industries be taken into account?
Should the EPA have the power to regulate carbon emissions from power plants and refineries?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on various ways of regulating.

fields.title: Were you supportive of the invasion of Iraq in 2003?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on withdrawals, various policies of occupation through the decade.

fields.title: Should the U.S. continue development of defense systems to intercept missiles?
Should marriage in the United States be explicitly defined as the union of a man and a woman?
Should skill level and potential contribution to society be the basis for granting immigrants  permanent U.S. residency?
Should the minimum wage be increased?
Should the U.S. expand offshore drilling?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on drilling regulations, locations for drilling, states and localities allowing drilling.

fields.title: Should law enforcement officers be allowed to search a home or business without the owner’s or the occupant’s permission or knowledge?
fields.summary: Related questions should focus on wire-tapping, searches without a court order.

fields.title: Should sex education programs advocate for use of contraceptives as opposed to abstinence?
fields.summary: Related questions concerning sexual education.

fields.title: Should the government be required to fully disclose all entities and organizations that have received federal funding?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on specific entities that should disclose their funding.

fields.title: Should companies involved in offshore drilling be required to equip their vessels with pollution control technology?
fields.summary: Other questions should focus on various safety standards.

fields.title: Should states have the authority to decide whether or not offshore drilling takes place in their waters?
Should religious schools be eligible for federal funding?
Should the government invest in research and development of more energy efficient technologies for our automobiles?
fields.summary: Other questions should focus on emissions and efficiency regulations for automobiles.

fields.title: Should the U.S. increase its use of nuclear power?
fields.summary: Other questions should focus on various funding for nuclear power, sharing and selling nuclear technology with other countries..

fields.title: Should the government provide loan gaurantees and tax breaks for technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions?
fields.summary: Follow-up questions should focus on specific renewable energy initiatives.

fields.title: Should Medicaid be expanded in order to cover more uninsured Americans?
Should the U.S. have a national, government-run health care system similar to those in Europe and Canada?
Should all U.S. citizens be required to have health insurance?
Should employers be required to take responsibility for a greater percentage of employees' health insurance expenses?
Should the government be funding environmental education programs for students and the public?
Should the U.S. government aid homeowners in financing energy efficiency renovations?
Should health insurance companies that issue long term plans be required to address disputed claims through a third-party review process?
Should openly gay individuals serve in the military?
Should a certain percentage of HIV/AIDS prevention funding be allocated only to programs that promote abstinence?
Should states be able to set their own water quality standards separate from those of the federal government?
Should the Food and Drug Administration have a less thorough review process for prescriptions drugs in order to increase availablility to patients?
Should makers of generic drugs be required to pay fees similar to those paid by brand-name manufacturers to have their drugs reviewed by the FDA?
Should the U.S. use a cap and trade system in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions?
Should the U.S. expand oil shale mining operations?
Should the federal government be promoting the development of more charter schools in the U.S.?
